articles.title: Genghis Khan
articles.context: The Shah's army was split by diverse internecine feuds and by the Shah's decision to divide his army into small groups concentrated in various cities. This fragmentation was decisive in Khwarezmia's defeats, as it allowed the Mongols, although exhausted from the long journey, to immediately set about defeating small fractions of the Khwarzemi forces instead of facing a unified defense. The Mongol army quickly seized the town of Otrar, relying on superior strategy and tactics. Genghis Khan ordered the wholesale massacre of many of the civilians, enslaved the rest of the population and executed Inalchuq by pouring molten silver into his ears and eyes, as retribution for his actions. Near the end of the battle the Shah fled rather than surrender. Genghis Khan ordered Subutai and Jebe to hunt him down, giving them 20,000 men and two years to do this. The Shah died under mysterious circumstances on a small island within his empire.

We can also infer that Genghis Khan and his army were very skilled in battle.

articles.title: European Union law
articles.context: While the Treaties and Regulations will have direct effect (if clear, unconditional and immediate), Directives do not generally give citizens (as opposed to the member state) standing to sue other citizens. In theory, this is because TFEU article 288 says Directives are addressed to the member states and usually "leave to the national authorities the choice of form and methods" to implement. In part this reflects that directives often create minimum standards, leaving member states to apply higher standards. For example, the Working Time Directive requires that every worker has at least 4 weeks paid holidays each year, but most member states require more than 28 days in national law. However, on the current position adopted by the Court of Justice, citizens have standing to make claims based on national laws that implement Directives, but not from Directives themselves. Directives do not have so called "horizontal" direct effect (i.e. between non-state parties). This view was instantly controversial, and in the early 1990s three Advocate Generals persuasively argued that Directives should create rights and duties for all citizens. The Court of Justice refused, but there are five large exceptions.

1. The Treaties and Regulations will have direct effect on citizens in the European Union, meaning they will have the power to enforce the rules without the need for member states to implement them.
2. Directives, on the other hand, do not generally give citizens standing to sue other citizens as they are directed towards the member states and do not specify an immediate implementation method.
3. Member states can choose to implement Directives according to their own form and methods, which often results in higher standards than the minimum requirements.
4. Citizens can enforce Directives through national laws, but not directly through the directives themselves.
5. Directives do not have "horizontal" direct effect, meaning they do not create rights and duties between non-state parties (citizens).
6. The Court of Justice has not agreed with the Advocate Generals who argued that Directives should create rights and duties for all citizens. However, there are five exceptions where citizens can enforce Directives.
7. The current position of the Court of Justice on the implementation of Directives was instantly controversial, as it deviates from the initial intention of the Treaties.

articles.title: Genghis Khan
articles.context: Genghis Khan is regarded as one of the prominent leaders in Mongolia's history. He is responsible for the emergence of the Mongols as a political and ethnic identity because there was no unified identity between the tribes that had cultural similarity. He reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during a time of almost endemic warfare between tribes. He is also given credit for the introduction of the traditional Mongolian script and the creation of the Ikh Zasag (Great Administration), the first written Mongolian law. "Ikh Zasag law adopted during Genghis Khan’s time in Mongolia had points to punish illegal matters related to corruption and bribery very heavily," Mongolian President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj noted. President Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as a leader from whom to learn for anti-corruption efforts as Genghis Khan sought equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth. "Chinggis (Genghis Khan)...was a man who deeply realized that the justice begins and consolidates with the equality of law, and not with the distinctions between people. He was a man who knew that the good laws and rules lived longer than fancy palaces," Elbegdorj said in his speech on the 850th anniversary of Chinggis Khaan's birth. In summary, Mongolians see him as the fundamental figure in the founding of the Mongol Empire and therefore the basis for Mongolia as a country.

completions.text:
1. Genghis Khan was a prominent leader in Mongolian history.
2. He played a significant role in the emergence of the Mongol ethnic identity.
3. Prior to his rule, there were many tribes with cultural similarities, but no unified identity.
4. Genghis Khan reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during a time of constant tribal warfare.
5. He is credited with introducing the traditional Mongolian script and creating the Ikh Zasag (Great Administration), the first written Mongolian law.
6. President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as an example to learn from when it comes to anti-corruption efforts and implementing equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth.
7. Elbegdorj highlights Genghis Khan's understanding of justice beginning with equality under the law, as opposed to distinctions between people.
8. Mongolians view Genghis Khan as the fundamental figure in the founding of the Mongol Empire and the basis for Mongolia as a country.

Implications:
1. Genghis Khan's leadership played a crucial role in shaping the cultural and political identity of Mongolia.
2. His emphasis on unity and stability during a time of internal conflict can be seen as a model for leaders seeking to promote national unity.
3. The introduction of the Mongolian script and the Ikh Zasag may serve as a reminder of the importance of preserving cultural heritage and establishing a system of governance.
4. The lessons learned from Genghis Khan's approach to corruption and equality can inform modern efforts to combat corruption and promote social justice.
5. Mongolia's recognition of Genghis Khan's significance in its history highlights the importance of acknowledging and celebrating the contributions of historical figures to a nation's identity.

articles.title: Chloroplast
articles.context: While primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor, secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two, as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event, when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it—much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story. The engulfed alga was broken down, leaving only its chloroplast, and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus, forming a chloroplast with three or four membranes—the two cyanobacterial membranes, sometimes the eaten alga's cell membrane, and the phagosomal vacuole from the host's cell membrane.

5. This resulted in a chloroplast with three or four membranes, including the two cyanobacterial membranes, sometimes the eaten alga's cell membrane, and the phagosomal vacuole from the host's cell membrane.

Implications:
1. The double membrane of primary chloroplasts is a result of their cyanobacterial origin.
2. Secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes due to the fusion of a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote and a chloroplast-containing alga.
3. Secondary chloroplasts may have three or four membranes, depending on the merging process.
4. The cell membrane of the eaten alga can sometimes remain in secondary chloroplasts.
5. The phagosomal vacuole from the host's cell membrane can also form part of the secondary chloroplast membrane system.

articles.title: Yuan dynasty
articles.context: The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the official terminology of the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely that of native Chinese dynasties, the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted of a mix of elements from different cultures. The Chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang, Song, as well as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties. Chinese advisers such as Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to Kublai's early court, and the central government administration was established within the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) to manage civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: 樞密院) to manage military affairs, and the Censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection. The actual functions of both central and local government institutions, however, showed a major overlap between the civil and military jurisdictions, due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance. Nevertheless, such a civilian bureaucracy, with the Central Secretariat as the top institution that was (directly or indirectly) responsible for most other governmental agencies (such as the traditional Chinese-style Six Ministries), was created in China. At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) that mainly dealt with finance was established (such as during the reign of Külüg Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.

completions.text:
The passage describes the establishment of the Yuan dynasty and its system of bureaucracy, which reflected a mix of cultures from different dynasties. It highlights the influence of Chinese advisers and the adoption of Chinese-style tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices. The passage also mentions the overlap between the civil and military jurisdictions, and the creation of a civilian bureaucracy with the Central Secretariat as the top institution. Finally, it notes that the Department of State Affairs was established in the Yuan dynasty, but it was usually abandoned shortly after its creation.

Implications:
1. The Yuan dynasty's bureaucracy was influenced by various cultures, including native Chinese dynasties, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists.
2. Chinese advisers played a significant role in the early development of the Yuan bureaucracy.
3. The Yuan dynasty adopted a Chinese-style tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices.
4. There was overlap between civil and military jurisdictions in the Yuan bureaucracy.
5. A civilian bureaucracy was created with the Central Secretariat as the top institution.
6. The Department of State Affairs was established in the Yuan dynasty but was usually abandoned shortly after its creation.

articles.title: Immune system
articles.context: Long-term active memory is acquired following infection by activation of B and T cells. Active immunity can also be generated artificially, through vaccination. The principle behind vaccination (also called immunization) is to introduce an antigen from a pathogen in order to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that particular pathogen without causing disease associated with that organism. This deliberate induction of an immune response is successful because it exploits the natural specificity of the immune system, as well as its inducibility. With infectious disease remaining one of the leading causes of death in the human population, vaccination represents the most effective manipulation of the immune system mankind has developed.

completions.text:
1. The passage discusses the concept of the immune system and its role in long-term memory.
2. It highlights that active immunity is acquired through infection and activation of B and T cells, and also through artificial means, like vaccination.
3. The principle behind vaccination is to introduce an antigen from a pathogen to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that particular pathogen without causing disease associated with that organism.
4. The passage emphasizes that vaccination represents the most effective manipulation of the immune system mankind has developed.
5. It highlights that infectious diseases remain a leading cause of death in the human population.

Implications:
1. The immune system plays a crucial role in developing long-term memory.
2. Artificial immunity, such as through vaccination, can be more effective than natural immunity acquired through infection.
3. Vaccination is a deliberate manipulation of the immune system for the prevention of infectious diseases.
4. Vaccination has been developed based on the understanding of the immune system's specificity and inducibility.
5. Effective vaccination strategies have had a significant impact on reducing the mortality rates caused by infectious diseases.

articles.title: Victoria (Australia)
articles.context: As of August 2010, Victoria had 1,548 public schools, 489 Catholic schools and 214 independent schools. Just under 540,800 students were enrolled in public schools, and just over 311,800 in private schools. Over 61 per cent of private students attend Catholic schools. More than 462,000 students were enrolled in primary schools and more than 390,000 in secondary schools. Retention rates for the final two years of secondary school were 77 per cent for public school students and 90 per cent for private school students. Victoria has about 63,519 full-time teachers.

Victoria (Australia)
As of August 2010, Victoria had 1,548 public schools, 489 Catholic schools and 214 independent schools. Just under 540,800 students were enrolled in public schools, and just over 311,800 in private schools. Over 61 per cent of private students attend Catholic schools. More than 462,000 students were enrolled in primary schools and more than 390,000 in secondary schools. Retention rates for the final two years of secondary school were 77 per cent for public school students and 90 per cent for private school students. Victoria has about 63,519 full-time teachers.

Personal hygiene is the practice of keeping one's body clean by washing with water and soap, and bathing or showering, as well as brushing teeth and cleaning other parts of the body. The practice of washing hands before eating and after using the bathroom reduces the spread of many diseases. Washing skin with soap reduces the number of germs (microscopic organisms that cause diseases) on the skin and thus reduces the chance of infection. Washing hair with shampoo removes dirt and the sebum (oil) that builds up on the head. The practice of foot washing (including treating foot fungus and athlete's foot) is also common.

4. Shampooing hair removes dirt and sebum, promoting cleanliness and preventing buildup.
5. Foot washing and treating foot fungus and athlete's foot are common practices.

Implications:

Passage:
Natural selection acts by eliminating less-fit phenotypes, resulting in a greater proportion of more-fit ones. Over time, this process produces adaptations: phenotypic changes, especially the loss or degradation of unused features, and new features supporting a new, different way of life. For example, an adaptation might be a parasite that evolves to be so small that it can subsist only in a single-celled form. In humans, adaptations include lactose tolerance, high cognitive function, and the exploitation of diverse modes of transportation.

Thought Process:
1. Natural selection acts by removing less-fit phenotypes from a population.
2. More-fit phenotypes are selected for in the population.
3. Over time, this process can lead to changes in the characteristics of the population.
4. These changes may result in adaptations to the environment or way of life.
5. Examples of adaptations include the evolution of certain features, the loss or degradation of unused features, and the development of new features.
6. These adaptations can result in the development of different survival strategies or behaviors.

Implications:
1. Natural selection drives evolutionary change by eliminating less-fit individuals.
2. Adaptations are a result of natural selection and enable species to better survive and reproduce in their environment.
3. Adaptations can be positive or negative for a species, and can influence the likelihood of their survival.
4. The development of new traits and behaviors through natural selection can lead to the diversification of species.
5. The loss or degradation of unused features through natural selection may be a cost of adaptation.

Homeostasis refers to a stable internal state, especially the stable set of parameters, or inputs, that are necessary for an organism to survive. In modern biology, homeostasis is maintained through the interaction of internal control systems, which act primarily by attempting to reduce variability in parameters like blood pressure or blood sugar levels. The science of homeostasis is termed homeostatistics. The term was introduced in 1932 by the American physiologist Walter Cannon.

Thought Process:

2. Maintaining homeostasis involves stabilizing internal parameters like blood pressure or blood sugar levels.
3. Internal control systems interact to maintain homeostasis by reducing variability in these parameters.
4. The study of homeostasis is known as homeostatistics.
5. The term "homeostasis" was introduced in 1932 by Walter Cannon.

Implications:
1. Homeostasis is crucial for the survival of an organism.
2. Various internal control systems work together to maintain homeostasis by stabilizing parameters such as blood pressure and blood sugar levels.
3. Understanding the mechanisms of homeostasis is essential for the study of biology and medicine.
4. Homeostatistics is a field of research focusing on the mechanisms and principles of maintaining homeostasis.
5. Walter Cannon's introduction of the term "homeostasis" in 1932 marked an important step in the study of this concept in biology.

It is a standardised dialect of Old Indo-Aryan, originating as Vedic Sanskrit and tracing its linguistic ancestry back to Proto-Indo-Iranian and Proto-Indo-European. Today it is listed as one of the 22 scheduled languages of India and is an official language of the state of Uttarakhand. As one of the oldest Indo-European languages for which substantial written documentation exists, Sanskrit holds a prominent position in Indo-European studies.

articles.title: Force
articles.context: This means that in a closed system of particles, there are no internal forces that are unbalanced. That is, the action-reaction force shared between any two objects in a closed system will not cause the center of mass of the system to accelerate. The constituent objects only accelerate with respect to each other, the system itself remains unaccelerated. Alternatively, if an external force acts on the system, then the center of mass will experience an acceleration proportional to the magnitude of the external force divided by the mass of the system.:19-1

1. Consider a closed system of particles.
2. In this system, there are no internal forces that are unbalanced.
3. When two objects in the system interact, they share an action-reaction force according to Newton's third law.
4. This action-reaction force will not cause the center of mass of the system to accelerate.
5. The acceleration of the objects will only be with respect to each other, not the overall system.
6. If an external force acts on the system, then the center of mass will experience an acceleration proportional to the magnitude of the external force divided by the mass of the system.

Implications:
1. In a closed system, internal forces do not contribute to the overall acceleration of the system.
2. The action-reaction forces between objects in a closed system do not affect the center of mass's motion.
3. The motion of individual objects within a closed system is relative to each other.
4. An external force can cause the center of mass of a system to accelerate, but the acceleration is proportional to the external force and inversely proportional to the mass of the system.

articles.title: American Broadcasting Company
articles.context: Edward John Noble, the owner of Life Savers candy, drugstore chain Rexall and New York City radio station WMCA, purchased the network for $8 million. Due to FCC ownership rules, the transaction, which was to include the purchase of three RCA stations by Noble, would require him to resell his station with the FCC's approval. The Commission authorized the transaction on October 12, 1943. Soon afterward, the Blue Network was purchased by the new company Noble founded, the American Broadcasting System. Noble subsequently acquired the rights to the "American Broadcasting Company" name from George B. Storer in 1944; its parent company adopted the corporate name American Broadcasting Companies, Inc. Woods retained his position as president and CEO of ABC until December 1949, and was subsequently promoted to vice-chairman of the board before leaving ABC altogether on June 30, 1951.

articles.title: Ctenophora
articles.context: Almost all species are hermaphrodites, in other words they function as both males and females at the same time – except that in two species of the genus Ocryopsis individuals remain of the same single sex all their lives. The gonads are located in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows, and eggs and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis. Fertilization is external in most species, but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch. Self-fertilization has occasionally been seen in species of the genus Mnemiopsis, and it is thought that most of the hermaphroditic species are self-fertile.

completions.text:

2. Two exceptions are found in the genus Ocryopsis, where individuals remain of the same sex throughout their lives.
3. Gonads, which produce eggs and sperm, are located in specific parts of the ctenophora's internal canal network.
4. Erosion and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis, with fertilization happening either externally or internally in certain cases.
5. Platyctenids, a group of ctenophora, use internal fertilization and protect their eggs in brood chambers until they hatch.
6. Some hermaphroditic ctenophora species have been observed to self-fertilize, allowing them to reproduce without the need for a partner of the opposite sex.

Implications:
1. Ctenophora have evolved a reproductive strategy that allows them to reproduce both externally and internally, providing flexibility and increasing their chances of successful reproduction.
2. Hermaphroditism is a common trait in many ctenophora species, which suggests that this reproductive strategy has been effective and has been maintained through evolution.
3. The presence of specific reproductive organs and the release of eggs and sperm through pores in the epidermis demonstrate the highly specialized reproductive adaptations found in ctenophora.
4. Platyctenids and other species that use internal fertilization provide insight into the diversity of reproductive strategies found in ctenophora, which may have implications for understanding the evolution of reproductive systems in other animals.
5. Self-fertilization among some hermaphroditic ctenophora suggests that asexual reproduction may occur in this group, which could have consequences for genetic diversity and population dynamics.

articles.title: Scottish Parliament
articles.context: The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak. Typically, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes, and succeeding speakers allocated less time. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate. Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.

articles.title: Chloroplast
articles.context: Recently, chloroplasts have caught attention by developers of genetically modified crops. Since, in most flowering plants, chloroplasts are not inherited from the male parent, transgenes in these plastids cannot be disseminated by pollen. This makes plastid transformation a valuable tool for the creation and cultivation of genetically modified plants that are biologically contained, thus posing significantly lower environmental risks. This biological containment strategy is therefore suitable for establishing the coexistence of conventional and organic agriculture. While the reliability of this mechanism has not yet been studied for all relevant crop species, recent results in tobacco plants are promising, showing a failed containment rate of transplastomic plants at 3 in 1,000,000.

completions.text:
1. Chloroplasts have gained interest from developers of genetically modified crops.
2. Most flowering plants inherit chloroplasts from the female parent.
3. Transgenes in chloroplasts cannot be disseminated by pollen, making them useful for genetically modifying plants.
4. This biological containment strategy is suitable for establishing the coexistence of conventional and organic agriculture.
5. While the reliability of this mechanism is still being studied for all relevant crop species, tobacco plants show promising results with a containment rate of 3 in 1,000,000.

Implications:
1. Chloroplasts have potential applications in the development of genetically modified crops.
2. Biologically containing genetically modified crops by using chloroplasts is a promising solution for coexistence of conventional and organic agriculture.
3. The success of chloroplast-based containment strategies needs further study and evaluation for various crop species.
4. The technology developed using chloroplasts in tobacco plants is a promising initial step towards the successful implementation of chloroplast-based biological containment strategies for other crop species.

articles.title: Chloroplast
articles.context: Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy. The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain. The molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma. The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma, the ATP is synthesized there, in position to be used in the dark reactions.

completions.text:
1. Chloroplasts use hydrogen ion gradients to generate ATP energy, similar to mitochondria.
2. Photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons from water.
3. These energized electrons are released down an electron transport chain.
4. Molecules between photosystems use the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space.
5. A concentration gradient is formed, with more hydrogen ions inside the thylakoid space than in the stroma.
6. Hydrogen ions flow back into the stroma through ATP synthase.
7. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to synthesize adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP.
8. Chloroplast ATP synthase is located in the stroma, making the ATP easily accessible for dark reactions.

Implications:
1. The function of chloroplasts in photosynthesis is to generate ATP energy using the potential energy stored in hydrogen ion gradients.
2. The energy from light is captured by photosystems and used to energize electrons from water.
3. The released electrons are harnessed through an electron transport chain, pumping hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space and forming a concentration gradient.
4. The hydrogen ions flow back into the stroma through ATP synthase, where the energy is used to synthesize ATP.
5. The location of ATP synthase in the stroma makes it easily accessible for the dark reactions in photosynthesis.
6. Chloroplasts play a crucial role in generating ATP energy for the plant, which is essential for its growth and development.

articles.title: Imperialism
articles.context: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the term has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility - a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

completions.text:
1. The passage discusses various views on imperialism in anglophone academic works.
2. It starts by mentioning the historical use of the term "imperialism" in the late 1870s, highlighting its original meaning and subsequent usage by supporters and critics of imperial policies.
3. The passage then introduces the liberal and Marxist perspectives on imperialism, mentioning John A. Hobson and Vladimir Lenin's contributions to the concept.
4. It points out the Marxist focus on the structural and systemic nature of imperialism, emphasizing capitalism and the need for expansion.
5. The text highlights the shifts in the meaning and application of the term imperialism over time, moving from specific policies and periods to a broader, longer-term understanding of the concept.
6. The passage also acknowledges the change in perspectives, reflecting a growing concern with power and Western dominance.

Implications:
1. The origins and context of the term "imperialism" have influenced its various meanings and interpretations over time.
2. Different perspectives on imperialism, such as the liberal and Marxist viewpoints, have contributed to its understanding and development.
3. The systemic and structural nature of imperialism has been a central focus of Marxist analysis, highlighting the role of capitalism and expansion.
4. The changing application of the term imperialism has led to a broader and longer-term understanding of the concept, reflecting shifts in sensibility and a growing concern with power dynamics.

articles.title: Huguenot
articles.context: A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins. Various hypotheses have been promoted. The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besançon Hugues (died 1532) and the religiously conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally housemates), referring to the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy"). Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators (all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a foiled attempt to wrest power in France from the influential House of Guise. The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.[citation needed]

5. Geneva was the centre of Calvinist movement

7. Term Huguenot purportedly applied to conspirators of the Amboise Plot

2. The derisive term Huguenot might have had underlying political connotations, particularly due to the association with an unpopular political move in France.
3. The adoption of the term as a nickname implies that the Reformed Church and their cause were politically unpopular at the time.
4. The story behind the origin of the term highlights the complex and tumultuous religious and political climate of the time, with the Huguenots being associated with religious reform and political intrigue.
5. The connections to a Swiss politician and the nickname "housemates" might be seen as reflecting on the Swiss-French conflict, further illustrating the complex connections between politics and religion during this period.
6. The connection to the Amboise Plot suggests that the term Huguenot might have been applied to specific, politically-oriented individuals involved in the conspiracy.

articles.title: Islamism
articles.context: "The Islamic State", formerly known as the "Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant" and before that as the "Islamic State of Iraq", (and called the acronym Daesh by its many detractors), is a Wahhabi/Salafi jihadist extremist militant group which is led by and mainly composed of Sunni Arabs from Iraq and Syria. In 2014, the group proclaimed itself a caliphate, with religious, political and military authority over all Muslims worldwide. As of March 2015[update], it had control over territory occupied by ten million people in Iraq and Syria, and has nominal control over small areas of Libya, Nigeria and Afghanistan. articles.title: Computational complexity theory
articles.context: Other important complexity classes include BPP, ZPP and RP, which are defined using probabilistic Turing machines; AC and NC, which are defined using Boolean circuits; and BQP and QMA, which are defined using quantum Turing machines. #P is an important complexity class of counting problems (not decision problems). 1. Computational complexity theory - This field is crucial for understanding the efficiency of algorithms and the inherent difficulty of solving problems. The passage introduces several complexity classes.

2. BPP, ZPP, and RP - These classes are related to probabilistic Turing machines. Probabilistic algorithms introduce some randomness and are useful when finding solutions to problems where deterministic algorithms may be inefficient or impractical.

3. AC and NC - These classes are related to Boolean circuits. These are a model of computation that allow us to understand the efficiency of parallel algorithms.

4. BQP and QMA - These classes are related to quantum Turing machines. Quantum algorithms can solve certain problems more efficiently than classical ones, and these complexity classes provide a framework for understanding those problems.

5. #P - This complexity class deals with counting problems. Unlike decision problems, counting problems require us to count the number of solutions to a given problem.

6. IP and AM - These are related to interactive proof systems, where a prover and a verifier interact to determine the solution to a problem.

7. ALL - This class represents the set of all decision problems. It is a crucial class because every problem can be solved by a Turing machine, but it is often used to demonstrate the limits of computational complexity theory.

Implications:

5. IP and AM highlight the importance of interactive proof systems in complexity theory and demonstrate how they can be used to verify solutions to difficult problems.

articles.title: Martin Luther
articles.context: Luther had published his German translation of the New Testament in 1522, and he and his collaborators completed the translation of the Old Testament in 1534, when the whole Bible was published. He continued to work on refining the translation until the end of his life. Others had translated the Bible into German, but Luther tailored his translation to his own doctrine. When he was criticised for inserting the word "alone" after "faith" in Romans 3:28, he replied in part: "[T]he text itself and the meaning of St. Paul urgently require and demand it. For in that very passage he is dealing with the main point of Christian doctrine, namely, that we are justified by faith in Christ without any works of the Law. ... But when works are so completely cut away – and that must mean that faith alone justifies – whoever would speak plainly and clearly about this cutting away of works will have to say, 'Faith alone justifies us, and not works'."

articles.title: Prime number
articles.context: Most early Greeks did not even consider 1 to be a number, so they could not consider it to be a prime. By the Middle Ages and Renaissance many mathematicians included 1 as the first prime number. In the mid-18th century Christian Goldbach listed 1 as the first prime in his famous correspondence with Leonhard Euler -- who did not agree. In the 19th century many mathematicians still considered the number 1 to be a prime. For example, Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of primes up to 10,006,721, reprinted as late as 1956, started with 1 as its first prime. Henri Lebesgue is said to be the last professional mathematician to call 1 prime. By the early 20th century, mathematicians began to accept that 1 is not a prime number, but rather forms its own special category as a "unit".

completions.text:
1. Early Greeks did not consider 1 to be a number, so it couldn't be a prime.
2. By the Middle Ages and Renaissance, some mathematicians considered 1 to be the first prime.
3. In the 18th century, Christian Goldbach and Leonhard Euler had differing opinions on whether 1 is prime.
4. In the 19th century, many mathematicians still considered 1 a prime.
5. Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of primes up to 10,067,219, printed in 1956, started with 1 as a prime.
6. Henri Lebesgue was reportedly the last professional mathematician to call 1 a prime.
7. By the early 20th century, mathematicians accepted that 1 is not a prime, but forms its own category as a "unit".

Implications:
1. The definition of prime numbers has changed over time, as the opinions of mathematicians have varied.
2. 1 has been considered a special case in mathematics, neither prime nor composite, for centuries.
3. The mathematical consensus on whether 1 is a prime number has evolved over time, influenced by new ideas and discoveries.
4. The classification of numbers is an ongoing area of study in mathematics, and may continue to evolve in the future.
5. The history of the concept of prime numbers provides insight into the development of mathematical ideas over time.
6. Understanding the history and evolution of mathematical definitions can inform our understanding of other mathematical concepts.

articles.title: Oxygen
articles.context: John Dalton's original atomic hypothesis assumed that all elements were monatomic and that the atoms in compounds would normally have the simplest atomic ratios with respect to one another. For example, Dalton assumed that water's formula was HO, giving the atomic mass of oxygen as 8 times that of hydrogen, instead of the modern value of about 16. In 1805, Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Alexander von Humboldt showed that water is formed of two volumes of hydrogen and one volume of oxygen; and by 1811 Amedeo Avogadro had arrived at the correct interpretation of water's composition, based on what is now called Avogadro's law and the assumption of diatomic elemental molecules.[a]

completions.text:
1. John Dalton's original atomic hypothesis did not account for complex atomic ratios in compounds.
2. He assumed water's formula was HO, resulting in an incorrect atomic mass of oxygen compared to hydrogen.
3. In 1805, Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Alexander von Humboldt showed water is formed from two volumes of hydrogen and one volume of oxygen.
4. Avogadro's law and the assumption of diatomic elemental molecules led to the correct interpretation of water's composition by 1811.

Implications:
1. Dalton's original hypothesis was not consistent with the true composition and ratios of elements in compounds.
2. Scientific observations and experiments can contradict early atomic theories.
3. Collaboration between scientists can lead to more accurate understanding of atomic structures.
4. Atomic models evolve as new discoveries and experimental evidence emerge.

questions.adapter_answer: The correct answer is that Gay-Lussac and von Humboldt did not discover the presence of a specific element in water. Their work focused on the composition of air, not water.

articles.title: French and Indian War
articles.context: In the spring of 1753, Paul Marin de la Malgue was given command of a 2,000-man force of Troupes de la Marine and Indians. His orders were to protect the King's land in the Ohio Valley from the British. Marin followed the route that Céloron had mapped out four years earlier, but where Céloron had limited the record of French claims to the burial of lead plates, Marin constructed and garrisoned forts. He first constructed Fort Presque Isle (near present-day Erie, Pennsylvania) on Lake Erie's south shore. He had a road built to the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. Marin constructed a second fort at Fort Le Boeuf (present-day Waterford, Pennsylvania), designed to guard the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. As he moved south, he drove off or captured British traders, alarming both the British and the Iroquois. Tanaghrisson, a chief of the Mingo, who were remnants of Iroquois and other tribes who had been driven west by colonial expansion. He intensely disliked the French (whom he accused of killing and eating his father). Traveling to Fort Le Boeuf, he threatened the French with military action, which Marin contemptuously dismissed.

articles.title: Pharmacy
articles.context: Consultant pharmacy practice focuses more on medication regimen review (i.e. "cognitive services") than on actual dispensing of drugs. Consultant pharmacists most typically work in nursing homes, but are increasingly branching into other institutions and non-institutional settings. Traditionally consultant pharmacists were usually independent business owners, though in the United States many now work for several large pharmacy management companies (primarily Omnicare, Kindred Healthcare and PharMerica). This trend may be gradually reversing as consultant pharmacists begin to work directly with patients, primarily because many elderly people are now taking numerous medications but continue to live outside of institutional settings. Some community pharmacies employ consultant pharmacists and/or provide consulting services.

- This trend may be reversing as consultant pharmacists work directly with patients.
- Community pharmacies may employ consultant pharmacists or provide consulting services.

Implications:

2. Nursing homes are a common setting for consultant pharmacists, but they are also expanding into other settings.
3. The trend towards consultant pharmacists working for large pharmacy management companies may be reversing.

articles.title: Fresno, California
articles.context: This vibrant and culturally diverse area of retail businesses and residences experienced a renewal after a significant decline in the late 1960s and 1970s.[citation needed] After decades of neglect and suburban flight, the neighborhood revival followed the re-opening of the Tower Theatre in the late 1970s, which at that time showed second and third run movies, along with classic films. Roger Rocka's Dinner Theater & Good Company Players also opened nearby in 1978,[citation needed] at Olive and Wishon Avenues. Fresno native Audra McDonald performed in the leading roles of Evita and The Wiz at the theater while she was a high school student. McDonald subsequently became a leading performer on Broadway in New York City and a Tony award winning actress. Also in the Tower District is Good Company Players' 2nd Space Theatre.

articles.title: Victoria and Albert Museum
articles.context: The Victoria and Albert Museum (often abbreviated as the V&A), London, is the world's largest museum of decorative arts and design, housing a permanent collection of over 4.5 million objects. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The V&A is located in the Brompton district of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in an area that has become known as "Albertopolis" because of its association with Prince Albert, the Albert Memorial and the major cultural institutions with which he was associated. These include the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum and the Royal Albert Hall. The museum is a non-departmental public body sponsored by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. Like other national British museums, entrance to the museum has been free since 2001.

articles.title: Computational complexity theory
articles.context: But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines. If we allow polynomial variations in running time, Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008, Chapter 1.2). This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

completions.text:
1. Computational complexity theory deals with the classification of computational problems based on their resource requirements, such as time and space.
2. The computation time for a problem can vary depending on the chosen machine model.
3. Some problems may have different time complexities in different machine models. For example, the problem {xx | x is any binary string} has linear time complexity on a multi-tape Turing machine but quadratic time complexity on a single-tape Turing machine.
4. Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related. This means that the difference in time complexity between two models is a polynomial function.
5. The complexity class P consists of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

Implications:
1. The choice of machine model can significantly impact the computation time required to solve a problem.
2. Cobham-Edmonds thesis suggests that time complexities between different models are related, but the relationship may not be simple.
3. The complexity class P defines a set of decision problems that can be solved efficiently by a deterministic Turing machine.
4. The set of function problems FP includes functions that can be computed efficiently by a deterministic Turing machine.
5. The notion of polynomially related time complexities between different models allows for the comparison of the efficiency of algorithms across different models.

articles.title: Packet switching
articles.context: Baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the RAND Corporation for the US Air Force into survivable communications networks, first presented to the Air Force in the summer of 1961 as briefing B-265, later published as RAND report P-2626 in 1962, and finally in report RM 3420 in 1964. Report P-2626 described a general architecture for a large-scale, distributed, survivable communications network. The work focuses on three key ideas: use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points, dividing user messages into message blocks, later called packets, and delivery of these messages by store and forward switching.

articles.title: Chloroplast
articles.context: While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons, photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted electrons at the end of an electron transport chain. Normally, the reenergized electrons are taken by NADP+, though sometimes they can flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more ATP. This is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled. Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants, which need more ATP than NADPH.

6. C4 plants need more ATP than NADPH.

Implications:

Let's read the following passage, think step by step, and then produce a list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content. We should first generate a "Thought Process" and then "Implications"

Passage:
Fluorine
This particular chemical bonding is common in molecular fluorine, and it is also stable in the diamond cubic variant of the solid form, but only up to 212 K (−61 °C). If the molecular gas is compressed under high pressure, the molecules will initially dissociate. A solid will be formed that has up to about 90% of the diamond cubic structure at low pressures, but higher pressures will produce a more crystalline solid.
Fluorine will form compounds with other non-metals, such as the halogens chlorine, bromine and iodine. For example, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are fluorine-based compounds that are volatile at room temperature and are used as refrigerants. The stability of these molecules depends on the electron-withdrawing ability of fluorine. They are non-reactive and have been implicated as ozone-depleting compounds, with hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) being designated to replace them. Hydrogen fluoride, however, forms hydrofluoric acid upon contact with wet air. The human body metabolizes certain elements into less toxic compounds, such as fluorides, so consuming fluoride over a long period of time will not normally be fatal. On the other hand, fluorides of less stable elements may have a greater toxicity as they precipitate out of solution and inhibit important metabolic processes.
Although some compounds of fluorine can be toxic, many, such as certain types of plastic or the Freon compounds, may not be harmful in themselves. Nonetheless, molecules that may not be toxic are usually polar and so are good at binding and inactivating important proteins, which may lead to poisoning. Most of the fluorine-containing drugs work due to their unexpected hydrophobic character. Many, however, are not intended for long-term use due to potential harmful reactions with other substances.

Thought Process:
1. Fluorine has a unique chemical bonding, forming molecular fluorine and the diamond cubic structure.
2. The stability of fluorine compounds is determined by the electron-withdrawing ability of fluorine.

While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons, photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted electrons at the end of an electron transport chain. articles.title: United Methodist Church
articles.context: Though John Wesley originally wanted the Methodists to stay within the Church of England, the American Revolution decisively separated the Methodists in the American colonies from the life and sacraments of the Anglican Church. In 1784, after unsuccessful attempts to have the Church of England send a bishop to start a new church in the colonies, Wesley decisively appointed fellow priest Thomas Coke as superintendent (bishop) to organize a separate Methodist Society. Together with Coke, Wesley sent a revision of the Anglican Prayerbook and the Articles of Religion which were received and adopted by the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784, officially establishing the Methodist Episcopal Church. The conference was held at the Lovely Lane Methodist Church, considered the Mother Church of American Methodism.

articles.title: Computational complexity theory
articles.context: The graph isomorphism problem is the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic. An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the graph isomorphism problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. The answer is not known, but it is believed that the problem is at least not NP-complete. If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy collapses to its second level. Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. The best algorithm for this problem, due to Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks has run time 2O(√(n log(n))) for graphs with n vertices.

articles.title: Normans
articles.context: The Normans were in contact with England from an early date. Because of this, Ethelred fled to Normandy in 1013, when he was forced from his kingdom by Sweyn Forkbeard. His stay in Normandy (until 1016) influenced him and his sons by Emma, who stayed in Normandy after Cnut the Great's conquest of the isle.

articles.title: Pharmacy
articles.context: The clinical pharmacist's role involves creating a comprehensive drug therapy plan for patient-specific problems, identifying goals of therapy, and reviewing all prescribed medications prior to dispensing and administration to the patient. The review process often involves an evaluation of the appropriateness of the drug therapy (e.g., drug choice, dose, route, frequency, and duration of therapy) and its efficacy. The pharmacist must also monitor for potential drug interactions, adverse drug reactions, and assess patient drug allergies while designing and initiating a drug therapy plan.

Implications:
1. **Patient-specific care**: Clinical pharmacists tailor medication plans to meet each patient's unique healthcare requirements.
2. **Medication appropriateness**: They assess whether the selected drugs are suitable for the condition being treated, considering all relevant factors.
3. **Adverse event prevention**: By monitoring medications, they aim to avoid adverse drug reactions and minimize the risk of complications.
4. **Drug interaction vigilance**: Clinical pharmacists ensure that there are no contraindications or adverse effects from concurrent medications.
5. **Patient safety**: Through their role, they contribute to safeguarding patients from potential harm associated with medication use.
6. **Continuous assessment**: Pharmacists monitor patient responses to treatments, adjusting plans as necessary to maintain optimal health outcomes.
7. **Enhanced medication management**: Their expertise helps streamline the management of multiple prescriptions, improving overall treatment effectiveness.

articles.title: Economic inequality
articles.context: For most of human history higher material living standards – full stomachs, access to clean water and warmth from fuel – led to better health and longer lives. This pattern of higher incomes-longer lives still holds among poorer countries, where life expectancy increases rapidly as per capita income increases, but in recent decades it has slowed down among middle income countries and plateaued among the richest thirty or so countries in the world. Americans live no longer on average (about 77 years in 2004) than Greeks (78 years) or New Zealanders (78), though the USA has a higher GDP per capita. Life expectancy in Sweden (80 years) and Japan (82) – where income was more equally distributed – was longer.

completions.text:
1. Economic inequality is a significant issue in most of human history.
2. Higher living standards (access to food, clean water, and warmth) led to better health and longer lives in poorer countries.
3. In recent decades, the pattern of higher incomes-longer lives has slowed down among middle-income countries and plateaued among the richest countries in the world.
4. Americans have a higher GDP per capita than Greeks and New Zealanders but a similar life expectancy.
5. In Sweden and Japan, where income was more equally distributed, life expectancy is longer.

Implications:
1. Economic inequality is a global issue.
2. Inequality affects not only the wealthy but also the poor.
3. Striving for economic growth alone is insufficient for improving health and life expectancy.
4. Income distribution is a crucial factor in achieving longer life expectancy.
5. More equal distribution of income, like in Sweden and Japan, leads to better overall health and life expectancy.

articles.title: Martin Luther
articles.context: In accordance with his father's wishes, Luther enrolled in law school at the same university that year but dropped out almost immediately, believing that law represented uncertainty. Luther sought assurances about life and was drawn to theology and philosophy, expressing particular interest in Aristotle, William of Ockham, and Gabriel Biel. He was deeply influenced by two tutors, Bartholomaeus Arnoldi von Usingen and Jodocus Trutfetter, who taught him to be suspicious of even the greatest thinkers and to test everything himself by experience. Philosophy proved to be unsatisfying, offering assurance about the use of reason but none about loving God, which to Luther was more important. Reason could not lead men to God, he felt, and he thereafter developed a love-hate relationship with Aristotle over the latter's emphasis on reason. For Luther, reason could be used to question men and institutions, but not God. Human beings could learn about God only through divine revelation, he believed, and Scripture therefore became increasingly important to him.

completions.text:
1. Luther wanted to study law but dropped out because he didn't believe it represented certainty.
2. He was drawn to theology and philosophy instead.
3. He was influenced by his tutors to be skeptical of everything and test it himself.
4. Philosophy didn't provide him with the assurance he needed about God.
5. Reason was not enough to lead to God, and it was important to focus on divine revelation through Scripture.

Implications:
1. Luther's decision to drop out of law school may have influenced his career path towards theology and philosophy.
2. The influence of his tutors may have helped shape Luther's critical thinking skills.
3. The importance of divine revelation through Scripture may have shaped Luther's religious views and theological beliefs.
4. The love-hate relationship with Aristotle may have influenced Luther's views on reason and philosophy.

articles.title: Harvard University
articles.context: James Bryant Conant (president, 1933–1953) reinvigorated creative scholarship to guarantee its preeminence among research institutions. He saw higher education as a vehicle of opportunity for the talented rather than an entitlement for the wealthy, so Conant devised programs to identify, recruit, and support talented youth. In 1943, he asked the faculty make a definitive statement about what general education ought to be, at the secondary as well as the college level. The resulting Report, published in 1945, was one of the most influential manifestos in the history of American education in the 20th century.

articles.title: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
articles.context: On 23 June 2005, Rep. Sherwood Boehlert, chairman of the House Science Committee, said this was a "misguided and illegitimate investigation" apparently aimed at intimidating scientists, and at his request the U.S. National Academy of Sciences arranged for its National Research Council to set up a special investigation. The National Research Council's report agreed that there were some statistical failings, but these had little effect on the graph, which was generally correct. Apollo moon landings
In June 1967 NASA selected McDonnell Aircraft to build the Apollo Lunar Module (LM). The first 11 LM prototypes included many different design modifications and performance improvements, which reflected the lessons learned during the programme's evolution. Beginning with the last LM, redesigned LMs included more of a role in the LM descent operations. Under the stewardship of Grumman, the final LM landing design featured many improvements over its predecessor, with the addition of a rendezvous radar in the service module, a completely new docking mechanism, and redesigned descent engines. Grumman had produced over 50 full-scale versions of the LM before it was finally selected to carry out the Apollo 9 and Apollo 10 flights, including a final evaluation unit that was tested with the Apollo 9 crew shortly before launch.
The LM carried the crew of the Apollo module during its descent from the lunar orbit, landing them on the lunar surface. Each LM descent stage included a desent rocket and fuel to power it on descent to the lunar surface. The Lunar Module's ascent stage would carry the crew of the Apollo module back to orbit, where it would rejoin the CSM. Several LM landings were originally planned in the Apollo 9 and Apollo 10 missions as the space shuttle was being developed, but all were cancelled as it was determined that not enough useful scientific data could be obtained. By the time Apollo 12 was flown, Grumman engineers were confident enough of the LM's design and construction that two landings were made in one mission, instead of making two launches a few days apart. The descent engine and ascent engine of the LM required ignition of a third engine during ascent. The throttle of the engine was one of the most complicated on the space shuttle and much study had to be done in the development of the guidance system. This was done in an effort to prevent a catastrophic failure such as the one which happened to the space shuttle Challenger.

Thought Process:
1. McDonnell Aircraft was chosen to build the Apollo Lunar Module (LM).
2. Many LM prototypes were produced, with design modifications and improvements reflecting the lessons learned during the program's evolution.
3. The final LM design included improvements such as rendezvous radar, a redesigned docking mechanism, and descent engines.
4. Grumman was responsible for the design, construction, and testing of the LM, producing over 50 full-scale versions.
5. The LM was used for lunar landings and included both descent and ascent stages.
6. The LM's descent engine and ascent engine required specific ignition procedures to ensure a successful landing and return to orbit.

Implications:
1. Budget constraints may lead to the cancellation of space missions.
2. Engineering lessons from prior projects can be applied to improve subsequent designs.
3. Collaboration between contractors (such as Grumman and NASA) is crucial for space exploration success.
4. Design and construction of complex systems require a significant amount of time and resources.
5. Flight testing and evaluation of LM prototypes can be time-consuming and costly.

articles.title: Martin Luther
articles.context: Luther devised the catechism as a method of imparting the basics of Christianity to the congregations. In 1529, he wrote the Large Catechism, a manual for pastors and teachers, as well as a synopsis, the Small Catechism, to be memorised by the people themselves. The catechisms provided easy-to-understand instructional and devotional material on the Ten Commandments, the Apostles' Creed, the Lord's Prayer, baptism, and the Lord's Supper. Luther incorporated questions and answers in the catechism so that the basics of Christian faith would not just be learned by rote, "the way monkeys do it", but understood.

completions.text:

1. Luther devised the catechism as a method of imparting the basics of Christianity to the congregations.
2. He wrote two versions: the Large Catechism (1529) and the Small Catechism.
3. The Large Catechism is for pastors and teachers, while the Small Catechism is for memorization by the people.
4. The catechisms cover topics such as the Ten Commandments, the Apostles' Creed, the Lord's Prayer, baptism, and the Lord's Supper.
5. The catechisms use a question-and-answer format to facilitate understanding.

Implications:
1. The catechism was a practical tool for teaching Christianity to people, including those without formal education.
2. Luther believed in making religious teachings accessible to the common people, not just to the clergy.
3. The question-and-answer format suggests that Luther wanted his followers to actively engage with the material, rather than just passively memorizing it.
4. The broad range of topics covered in the catechism indicates that Luther aimed to provide a comprehensive overview of Christian doctrine.
5. The catechism may have contributed to Luther's influence on the Protestant Reformation, by spreading his ideas about Christianity more broadly and deeply.
6. The development of the catechism could also be seen as an early example of educational materials being created specifically for use in religious instruction.

articles.title: Immune system
articles.context: In contrast, during wake periods differentiated effector cells, such as cytotoxic natural killer cells and CTLs (cytotoxic T lymphocytes), peak in order to elicit an effective response against any intruding pathogens. As well during awake active times, anti-inflammatory molecules, such as cortisol and catecholamines, peak. There are two theories as to why the pro-inflammatory state is reserved for sleep time. First, inflammation would cause serious cognitive and physical impairments if it were to occur during wake times. Second, inflammation may occur during sleep times due to the presence of melatonin. Inflammation causes a great deal of oxidative stress and the presence of melatonin during sleep times could actively counteract free radical production during this time.

completions.text:

2. The immune system is more active during sleep periods, specifically in producing pro-inflammatory molecules like cytokines.
3. There are two theories as to why the pro-inflammatory state is reserved for sleep time: (a) inflammation would cause serious cognitive and physical impairments if it were to occur during wake times and (b) the presence of melatonin during sleep times may counteract free radical production.
4. Anti-inflammatory molecules peak during wake times to counteract the pro-inflammatory state.

Implications:
1. The immune system's activity during sleep periods is specifically aimed at fighting inflammation, indicating a crucial role of sleep in maintaining the body's overall health.
2. The increased activity of pro-inflammatory molecules during sleep could be a reason for the common feeling of fatigue and sluggishness during wake periods, especially if there is not enough sleep.
3. The presence of melatonin during sleep may help protect the body from the negative effects of inflammation, making sleep essential for maintaining healthy aging.
4. The peak of anti-inflammatory molecules during wake periods suggests a balancing act between inflammation and anti-inflammation, and the disruption of this balance could lead to various health problems.
5. More research is needed to understand the relationship between sleep, inflammation, and cognitive function, and how disrupted sleep can impact immune system activity.

Impression management is the process through which individuals intentionally or unintentionally manage how others perceive them in social interactions. The term originated in the social sciences in the 1950s. In psychology, impression management is closely related to notions of performance, frontstage behavior, social positioning, personal identity, and social identity. In communication studies, impression management is related to the notion of strategies, tactics, and operations of self-presentation and self-disclosure. There are many theories and models of impression management, from Carl Hovland's initial classical expectancy theory to Blas_Menuen's person perception model.

Passage:
Disposition effect (PE) refers to the tendency of investors to hold losing investments too long and sell winning investments too soon. Additionally, with regard to stocks and mutual funds, the PE can increase account turnover, reduce the level of diversification in an investor's portfolio, or make non-strategic tax decisions. These have the potential to decrease investment performance. The PE suggests a violation of rational theory, which would predict that investors will be indifferent to the identity of the asset when evaluating the decision to sell.
Several explanations of the PE have been developed. First, Fama and French argue that the PE is due to irrational investors who are more willing to sell winners for tax gains. In addition, Hirst et al. found that the PE may be a result of intramarket correlations of stock returns, or 'beta dogma'. The PE could also be explained by the asymmetric nature of stock market decisions: the subject receives more information about a stock when it has a large loss than when it has a similar-sized gain. Less information is received when an investor experiences a gain because "it is easier to endow stocks with intangible psychological assets when gains are realized rather than losses." Lastly, the PE may be caused by investors' desire to avoid the emotional and psychological costs associated with selling investments. These explanations have been largely supported by peer-reviewed empirical research.
It has been suggested that the PE can be reduced by a four-step process: awareness of the effect, recording of original investment objectives, establishment of new objectives in terms of portfolio composition and appropriate diversification, and regular portfolio review and restructuring.

Thought Process:
1. Disposition effect refers to the tendency of investors to hold losing investments too long and sell winning investments too soon.
2. The PE can have negative consequences, such as increasing account turnover, reducing diversification, and leading to non-strategic tax decisions.
3. The PE is considered a violation of rational theory, which would predict that investors should be indifferent to the identity of the asset when deciding to sell.
4. Different explanations have been developed to explain the PE, including irrational investors being more willing to sell winners for tax gains, intramarket correlations of stock returns, the asymmetric nature of stock market decisions, and the desire to avoid emotional and psychological costs associated with selling investments.
5. Empirical research has largely supported these explanations.
6. The PE can be reduced by a four-step process: awareness of the effect, recording of original investment objectives, establishment of new objectives in terms of portfolio composition and appropriate diversification, and regular portfolio review and restructuring.

Implications:
1. Investors can benefit from being aware of the disposition effect and its potential negative consequences.
2. Recording and regularly reviewing original investment objectives can help investors make informed decisions about when to buy and sell investments.
3. Establishing new objectives in terms of portfolio composition and appropriate diversification can help reduce the impact of the PE on investment performance.
4. Regular portfolio review and restructuring can help investors manage the PE and make better investment decisions.
5. The dispositional effect highlights the importance of understanding and managing the psychological factors that can influence investment decisions.

Passage:
Open ring
There are many different variations on the open ring system. Some of the best known are the originational divide and play it again systems. In open ring theory, a ring refers to a scenario in which players eliminate opponents by submitting cards with a higher rank than theirs. In originational divide, players submit cards and the person who submitted the highest card keeps the pot for this round and becomes the next dealer. In play it again, there is no dealer. Each player begins by placing the agreed upon stake (or ante) and submits a single card. The person with the highest card wins the pot and the round. This new winner then places their ante and submits a new card. They continue to do this for the duration of the round. After a round has ended, all players ante as they did the first time and begin submitting cards again. In both originational divide and play it again, the winner is the first person to win x number of rounds.
Play it again can be played as a progressive, where the ante is doubled between hands, or a standard game where the ante remains constant throughout the game. There are variations, like the All Play Card which allows each player to use two cards and the All Play Card Triple that allows the player to use three cards.

Thought Process:
1. Open ring theory refers to a system where players eliminate opponents by submitting cards with a higher rank than theirs.
2. There are different variations of open ring systems, including the originational divide and play it again systems.
3. In originational divide, the person who submits the highest card keeps the pot for that round and becomes the next dealer.
4. In play it again, there is no dealer, and each player places an ante and submits a single card. The winner is the first person to win x number of rounds.
5. Play it again can be played as a progressive game, where the ante is doubled between hands, or a standard game with a constant ante.
6. Variations of play it again include the All Play Card, which allows players to use two cards

articles.title: Fresno, California
articles.context: Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

3. **Current Water Crisis**: Highlight the current water crisis facing the region, emphasizing the importance of water management in the Central Valley.
